Common.Instruction: Read again and fill in the blanks with the correct names.
Common.Title: Reading Task 3

Content.Stimulus:
Teenagers from around the world:

Andor
Now that I'm fifteen my parents give me five thousand forint per month. I know that it's not much, and I hate digging and planting flowers and stuff. But I’m going to the kerepar store next month and I really need the money. I'm tired of walking to school every day, and it’ll be great to ride past my friends so fast!

Helga
My mother doesn't give me much pocket money each week – just a few hundred kronor – and you can't buy much with that, can you? Usually I spend it on saelgaeti from the local stores. I really like the lemon flavored ones, but I usually give half of them to my baby brother. My parents are always too busy to look after him.

Loto
Even though my parents are some of the wealthiest people on the island, they only give me twenty tala per week. After all the time that I spent helping my little sister to learn stuff, they only give me this little amount of money. I'm saving my money to go to the tusi store. They're selling the latest tusi by the famous novelist, Jane Mino. I love her adventure stories!

Mamello
Each month I get forty loti from my dad to spend. His shirts always need cleaning after he finishes work, so he gives them to me. I’d love to buy a new bike or something, but I'm saving all my money for the new apara I've seen in the store. I want something great to wear with my new shoes at my cousin's wedding next month.

Arturo
My sixteenth birthday was last week, and can you believe, my father gave me one hundred sol! I've never had this much money in my whole life. Next week, I'm going straight to the sapatu store to buy the best that I can. No more walking with bare feet for me! Now I can really give our pets some good exercise.
